results.title: 7 countries with the highest tiger population
results.description: However, due to shrinking forests and growing threats, their numbers have declined over the years. results.title: Project Tiger - Wikipedia
results.description: Based on the result of these surveys, the total tiger population was estimated at 1,411 individuals ranging from 1,165 to 1,657 adult and sub-adult tigers of more than 1.5 years of age. The 2010 National Tiger Assessment estimated the total population of wild tigers in India at 1,706.

results.title: Express View on dip in tiger numbers in Telangana, Chhattisgarh, Jharkhand and Odisha: A new conservation challenge | The Indian Express
results.description: Conservationists were jolted in 2006 when the country’s tiger population plummeted to an all-time low of about 1,400. Course corrections in wildlife management have led to the majestic animal staging a remarkable recovery since that crisis. The country’s protected areas have more than 3,600 ...

results.title: Explained: State of India’s tiger prey, why challenges to their habitat need to be addressed | Explained News - The Indian Express
results.description: Spotted deer, sambar, and gaur populations are thriving in large parts of India, but declining in Odisha, Jharkhand, and Chhattisgarh. This matters for tigers, and for wildlife conservation as a whole.

results.title: Demographics of India - Wikipedia
results.description: In 2017 its population growth rate was 0.98%, ranking 112th in the world; in contrast, from 1972 to 1983, India's population grew by an annual rate of 2.3%. results.title: International Tiger Day - Wikipedia
results.description: In India, the tiger population has shown a significant increase, reaching 3,682, up from 2,967 in 2018. This marks a notable rise of almost 24% within a span of four years. These figures reflect a positive trend, surpassing the 3,167 tigers reported by Prime Minister Narendra Modi during an ...

results.title: Tiger - Wikipedia
results.description: Bhutan's first Tiger Action Plan implemented during 2006–2015 revolved around habitat conservation, human–wildlife conflict management, education and awareness; the second Action Plan aimed at increasing the country's tiger population by 20% until 2023 compared to 2015.

results.title: Economy of India - Wikipedia
results.description: India is home to 75 per cent of the world's wild tiger population.The big cats like lion, tiger, leopard, cheetah, snow leopard, jaguar and puma were on the brink of extinction. With hunting and encroachment, their numbers dropped to a mere 20.
